Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Situation2: They conduct an in-depth consultation with a patient taking multiple high-risk medications to prevent dangerous interactions.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the pharmacy wall, my mind racing. My shift was nearly over, but Mrs. Lee, a regular patient, had just arrived with a new prescription. She was already on several high-risk medications, and I knew she needed a thorough consultation to prevent any dangerous interactions. As a pharmacist, I couldn’t rush this—her safety depended on my careful attention. But then my phone buzzed with a message from my partner: “Don’t forget, you promised to pick up the Nintendo for Jamie today. He’s been talking about it all week.” I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. Jamie had been saving up, and I’d promised to make it special by buying it together after work. I wanted to keep my word, to give him that joy and show him I could provide for our family. But Mrs. Lee was waiting, trusting me with her health. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each expectation pulling me in a different direction. I stood there, torn, knowing I couldn’t give both the attention they deserved at the same time.
